verses.verse: (Job Reaffirms His Innocence) Then Job answered:
“I have heard many such things; miserable comforters are you all.
(Job 6.26) Have windy words no limit? Or what provokes you that you keep on talking?
(Ps 22.7; 109.25; Lam 2.15; Mt 27.39) I also could talk as you do, if you were in my place; I could join words together against you and shake my head at you.
I could encourage you with my mouth, and the solace of my lips would assuage your pain.
“If I speak, my pain is not assuaged, and if I refrain, how much of it leaves me?
(Job 7.3) Surely now God has worn me out; he has (Heb you have) made desolate all my company.
(Job 10.17; 19.20) And he has (Heb you have) shriveled me up, which is a witness against me; my leanness has risen up against me, and it testifies to my face.
(Job 13.24; Ps 35.16) He has torn me in his wrath and hated me; he has gnashed his teeth at me; my adversary sharpens his eyes against me.
(Ps 22.13; 35.15; Lam 3.30; Mic 5.1) They have gaped at me with their mouths; they have struck me insolently on the cheek; they mass themselves together against me.
(Job 1.15, 17) God gives me up to the evil and casts me into the hands of the wicked.
(Job 9.17) I was at ease, and he broke me in two; he seized me by the neck and dashed me to pieces; he set me up as his target;
(Job 19.12; 20.25; 27.22) his archers surround me. He slashes open my kidneys and shows no mercy; he pours out my gall on the ground.
(Job 9.17; Joel 2.7) He bursts upon me again and again; he rushes at me like a warrior.
(Gen 37.34; Job 30.19) I have sewed sackcloth upon my skin and have laid my strength in the dust.
My face is red with weeping, and deep darkness is on my eyelids,
(Job 27.4) though there is no violence in my hands, and my prayer is pure.
(Ps 66.18, 19; Isa 26.21) “O earth, do not cover my blood; let my outcry find no resting place.
(Rom 1.9) Even now my witness is in heaven, and my advocate is on high.
My friends scorn me; my eye pours out tears to God,
(1 Kings 8.45; Ps 9.4) that he would maintain the right of a mortal with God, as (Syr Vg Tg: Heb and) one does for a neighbor.
(Eccl 12.5) For when a few years have come, I shall go the way from which I shall not return.
